title: 113_s2952
content: The "Evidence-Based Policymaking Commission Act of 2014" establishes the "Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking" in the executive branch. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, with specific expertise required for each appointment. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, with expertise in program administration, database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. Members are appointed by the Speaker and the Minority Leader of the House of Representatives based on their academic research, data expertise, and database management skills. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by the President, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, the Minority Leader of the House, and the Majority Leader of the Senate. Members are required to have expertise in program administration, database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. Three members appointed by the Majority Leader of the Senate must have expertise in academic research, data analysis, or program administration, while one member must specialize in database management, confidentiality, and privacy. Three members appointed by the Majority Leader of the Senate must have expertise in academic research, data analysis, or program administration, while one member must specialize in database management, confidentiality, and privacy. The Minority Leader of the Senate appoints three members, two of whom should be academic researchers, data experts, or have experience in program administration, and one with expertise in database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. The Commission members appointed by the Senate include individuals with expertise in academic research, data analysis, program administration, database management, confidentiality, and privacy. The President selects the chairperson, and the Speaker of the House selects the co-chairperson. The President and Speaker of the House appoint members with expertise in economics, statistics, program evaluation, data security, confidentiality, or database management to the Commission. Appointments must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Appointments to the Commission must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the duration of the Commission without pay, and travel expenses are covered. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members of the Commission serve without pay and are allowed travel expenses for services performed away from their homes or regular places of business. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will conduct a study on data inventory, infrastructure, and protocols related to Federal policymaking. Recommendations will be made on integrating administrative data for program evaluation and policy research. The Commission will study integrating administrative data for program evaluation, policy research, and cost-benefit analyses. Recommendations will be made on modifying data infrastructure and protocols to fulfill objectives, incorporating outcomes measurement, randomized controlled trials, and impact analysis into program design. The Commission will study creating a clearinghouse for program and survey data, including relevant administrative datasets for program evaluation and Federal policy-making. The Commission will consider creating a clearinghouse for program and survey data, evaluating relevant administrative datasets, survey data linkages, and legal barriers. The Commission will evaluate creating a clearinghouse for program and survey data, including identifying survey datasets, legal barriers, data-sharing infrastructure, funding, access for researchers, and limitations on data use. The Commission will assess data-sharing infrastructure, funding for a self-funded clearinghouse, access for qualified researchers, limitations on data use, privacy protection, and using research results to improve program design and inform policymakers. Incentives for interagency data sharing will also be considered. The Commission will submit a detailed report to the President and Congress with findings on protecting information, using research results to inform policymakers, and incentives for interagency data sharing. The Commission will submit a detailed report to the President and Congress with findings on improving program effectiveness, data accuracy, and recommendations for legislation or administrative actions. The report deadline is 15 months after a majority vote by the Commission. The Commission will submit a report with findings and recommendations for legislation or administrative actions within 15 months of a majority vote. Administrative data refers to information generated by an agency for Federal programs. The Commission members are appointed according to section 3. Administrative data is defined as information generated or collected by an agency for Federal programs. The Commission operates according to section 5 and has specific powers. The Commission operates according to section 5 and has specific powers. Administrative Assistance: Heads of various agencies advise and consult with the Commission on matters within their areas of responsibility. Agencies include Office of Management and Budget, Bureau of the Census, Internal Revenue Service, Bureau of Economic Analysis, Bureau of Labor Statistics, Department of Health and Human Services, Department of Agriculture, Department of Housing and Urban Development, Social Security Administration, Department of Education, and Department of Justice. The Commission, as determined by the Commission, shall meet within 30 days of appointing a majority of its members and as scheduled by the chairperson or co-chairperson. Rules of procedure will be established by the chairperson and co-chairperson. The Commission will meet within 30 days of appointing a majority of its members, as scheduled by the chairperson or co-chairperson. Rules of procedure will be established with a quorum requirement. The Commission may hold hearings as needed. The Commission, with majority approval, will establish written rules of procedure including a quorum requirement. It may hold hearings, contract with government and private agencies, and use the United States mails. The Commission, with majority approval, can establish rules of procedure, hold hearings, contract with agencies, use the United States mails, accept gifts, and work with the Census Bureau and NAPA. The Commission can use the United States mails, accept gifts, and work with the Census Bureau and NAPA for administration. Funding is provided by principal statistical agencies upon request. The Director of the Census will contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to administer the Commission. Principal statistical agencies can provide funds, up to $2,000,000, for the Commission's operations. The Director can receive up to $2,000,000 for the Commission's operations, as defined in the report by the Office of Management and Budget. SEC. 6. PERSONNEL. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the chairperson with the concurrence of the co-chairperson, paid at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director may appoint additional staff and procure temporary services as needed. The Director of the Commission may appoint additional staff and procure temporary services as needed under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. The Commission will terminate within 18 months of the enactment of this Act.
